item.title:
Such an internal battle between letting myself thoroughly enjoy the good news while knowing this can all change again on a whim.
You could say I presently have trust issues.

item.title:
Monday:
“You really should’ve waited to buy the dip. Told you.“
- Guy
Today:
“Wait you haven’t bought the bought the dip. What were you waiting for. Told you.”
- Same guy
Tomorrow:
“Whatever narrative fits the last day of price action. I told you.”
- still same guy

item.title: R to @StockMarketNerd: Might be sooner than later

R to @StockMarketNerd: People taking this as a bottom call shouldn’t.
Entirely possible that we’ve found a local bottom. Entirely possible we haven’t.
But it has been a crazy few months.
I’m proud of the fact that we stayed the course and stuck to our process when many bright, highly regarded individuals were running for the hills and calling for the next depression.
That’s what matters. Not if our long term holdings fall or don’t fall another few percent lower before finding the exact bottom.
item.description:
People taking this as a bottom call shouldn’t.

That’s what matters. Not if our long term holdings fall or don’t fall another few percent lower before finding the exact bottom.

item.title: I’d be willing to sacrifice having to see a ton of the “this stock will 100x” threads on here again in exchange for the trade war ending
item.description: I’d be willing to sacrifice having to see a ton of the “this stock will 100x” threads on here again in exchange for the trade war ending

item.title: R to @StockMarketNerd: Yes I know I am reaching.

The silver lining about the trade war?
Usually retail is the cohort that has no idea what is going to happen.
Over the last two months, neither retail nor institutions have had any idea what is going to happen.
In a way… it has leveled the playing field.
item.description:

Usually retail is the cohort that has no idea what is going to happen.

item.title:
RT by @StockMarketNerd: Every single bear market rally will be called a dead cat bounce.
& everyone calling it that will be right until they aren't.
Is this just a dead cat bounce? Not sure. I'll be able to confidently tell you in hindsight.
item.description:

item.title:
RT by @StockMarketNerd: Bond markets can only show so much fragility… the administration can only see their economic approval rating fall so far…
Before changes are made to improve liquidity & sentiment.
I personally don’t want to pick a spot to go all in during times like these.
& I don’t want to be sitting in cash when the next positive headline inevitably breaks.
I want to exercise balance. I want to maintain needed flexibility to react. I don’t want to predict.
item.description:
Bond markets can only show so much fragility… the administration can only see their economic approval rating fall so far…

Before changes are made to improve liquidity & sentiment.

I personally don’t want to pick a spot to go all in during times like these.

& I don’t want to be sitting in cash when the next positive headline inevitably breaks.

I want to exercise balance. I want to maintain needed flexibility to react. I don’t want to predict.

item.title:
RT by @StockMarketNerd: Markets are rigged for bulls.
They go up the vast majority of the time.
And if they go down? If something breaks? Changes are made or the Fed steps in to save the day.
Every time. That is our reality.
We can volunteer to have it rigged against us & complain. Or we can choose to have it rigged for us & carefully take advantage.
To me, the choice is clear.
item.description:
Markets are rigged for bulls.

They go up the vast majority of the time.

And if they go down? If something breaks? Changes are made or the Fed steps in to save the day.

Every time. That is our reality.

We can volunteer to have it rigged against us & complain. Or we can choose to have it rigged for us & carefully take advantage.

To me, the choice is clear.
